citations.narrative:
The back side of a capuchin enclosure had an elevated wooden platform with adhered, brownish/gray colored, organic
type material within the worn cracks and rough ridges on the top surface. Surfaces which cannot be readily cleaned and
sanitized such as unsealed or porous, cracked surfaces can trap debris, bacteria, or other harmful organisms. All surfaces
must be maintained on a regular basis. Surfaces of housing facilities that cannot be readily cleaned or sanitized must be
replaced when worn or soiled.
Correct by 03/15/2024.

A room used for food preparation, food and supply storage, and for cleaning animal dishes is in need of general
housekeeping and cleaning. There was an accumulation of several, old cobwebs in the rafters directly above the
food/supply areas with some approximately 1ft. X 1ft. in size. Additionally, there were accumulations of dust/debris and
cobwebs along the walls behind food storage appliances. Regular cleaning and housekeeping is necessary to protect the
health of animals, to prevent the harborage of pests and to reduce the potential for spread of disease. Premises (buildings
and grounds) shall be kept clean and in good repair in order to protect the animals from injury and to facilitate the
prescribed husbandry practices set forth in this subpart.
Correct by 03/15/2024.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The facility provides enrichment items and opportunities for its birds; however, a written environmental enhancement plan
for birds had not been developed by the facility and was not available for review. This plan is necessary to promote the
psychological well-being of birds. Exhibitors must develop, document, and follow a species-appropriate plan that has been
approved by the attending veterinarian. The plan must be in accordance with the regulations and with currently accepted
professional standards as cited in appropriate professional journals or reference guides. At a minimum, the plan must
address each of the following: social grouping, environmental enrichment, special considerations, restraint devices, and
exemptions.
Correct by 03/28/2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
ALEXANDRA ANDRICOS, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.75(c)(2) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
The back side of a capuchin enclosure had an elevated wooden platform with adhered, brownish/gray colored, organic 
type material within the worn cracks and rough ridges on the top surface. Surfaces which cannot be readily cleaned and 
sanitized such as unsealed or porous, cracked surfaces can trap debris, bacteria, or other harmful organisms. All surfaces 
must be maintained on a regular basis. Surfaces of housing facilities that cannot be readily cleaned or sanitized must be 
replaced when worn or soiled. 
 
Correct by 03/15/2024. 
3.131(c) 
   
Sanitation. 
A room used for food preparation, food and supply storage, and for cleaning animal dishes is in need of general 
housekeeping and cleaning. There was an accumulation of several, old cobwebs in the rafters directly above the 
food/supply areas with some approximately 1ft. X 1ft. in size. Additionally, there were accumulations of dust/debris and 
cobwebs along the walls behind food storage appliances. Regular cleaning and housekeeping is necessary to protect the 
health of animals, to prevent the harborage of pests and to reduce the potential for spread of disease. Premises (buildings 
and grounds) shall be kept clean and in good repair in order to protect the animals from injury and to facilitate the 
prescribed husbandry practices set forth in this subpart. 
 
Correct by 03/15/2024. 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
The facility provides enrichment items and opportunities for its birds; however, a written environmental enhancement plan 
for birds had not been developed by the facility and was not available for review. This plan is necessary to promote the 
psychological well-being of birds. Exhibitors must develop, document, and follow a species-appropriate plan that has been 
approved by the attending veterinarian. The plan must be in accordance with the regulations and with currently accepted 
professional standards as cited in appropriate professional journals or reference guides. At a minimum, the plan must

address each of the following: social grouping, environmental enrichment, special considerations, restraint devices, and 
exemptions. 
 
Correct by 03/28/2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
ALEXANDRA ANDRICOS, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
